questions.question_text: Which statement accurately describes a Tanzu Spherelet?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is the correct answer

D is the correct 

About Spherelets

A Spherelet is a kubelet that enables ESXi hosts to form a Kubernetes cluster.
The Spherelet performs the following functions:
• Communicates with the control plane VMs
• Manages node configuration
• Starts vSphere pods
• Monitors vSphere pods

on the other hand, Supervisor Cluster Control Plane

The supervisor cluster deploys a set of three control plane VMs that provide API access to the supervisor cluster.
The control plane VM serves as an endpoint for users to manage their namespaces using the familiar kubectl CLI.

From VMware Cloud Foundation: Deploy, Configure, Manage [V5.0] Lesson Book

Selected Answer: C
I would say C https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/vmware-vsphere-with-tanzu/GUID-2581B3E5-6A80-4306-B88E-35DE6AC81008.html

Correct answer is D.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/8.0/vsphere-with-tanzu-concepts-planning/GUID-3E4E6039-BD24-4C40-8575-5AA0EECBBBEC.html
Spherelet. An additional process called Spherelet is created on each host. It is a kubelet that is ported natively to ESXi and allows the ESXi host to become part of the Kubernetes cluster.

comments.content:
Correct answer is D.
The spherelet runs on the ESXi host.

discussion.content: B. The Spherelet runs as an agent on the vCenter server of the Tanzu-enabled VCF workload domain.

choices.A: A Spherelet runs as a VM on the supervisor cluster.
choices.B: The Spherelet runs as an agent on the vCenter server of the Tanzu-enabled VCF workload domain.
choices.D: The Spherelet communicates with the control plane’s API server.
choices.C: A Spherelet upgrade does not have any impact on the PODs running on the supervisor cluster node.

questions.question_text: What is the correct sequence of steps to add a new VI Workload Domain in a VMware Cloud Foundation environment?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
host commissioning does a DNS check, if DNS is not configured the host can not be commissioned, answer is A

Why do we need DNS for a VI deployment?
Would 100% need DNS if deploying a Tanzu cluster

Selected Answer: A
It is A - C can't be possible because we need the DNS for Deployment. And the right Sequence is First Network Pool and then Comission the Hosts

Selected Answer: C
Order listed here, halfway down page
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-Foundation/5.0/vcf-getting-started/GUID-C000FB7D-5A4C-4AA7-AEAB-D67F335BCB21.html

comments.content: Are you sure that is A and not D?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
First NetWorkPool Second Commision host

questions.question_text: What are the minimum hardware requirements to run customer workloads within a cluster in a VI workload domain considering maintenance operations without risking availability?

choices.D: Three vSAN Ready Nodes with two 25GbE NICs
choices.A: Two vSAN Ready Nodes (ROBO) with two 10GbE NICs, and optionally one 1GbE BMC NIC
choices.C: Three vSAN Ready Nodes with two 10GbE NICs, and optionally one 1GbE BMC NIC
choices.B: Four vSAN Ready Nodes with two 25GbE NICs

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BCE
Here's an extract of the VCF's admin guide v4.4

"You can remove NSX Edge nodes from an NSX Edge Cluster that you created with SDDC Manager if you need to scale down to meet business needs.

Prerequisites

-The NSX Edge cluster must be available in the SDDC Manager inventory and must be Active.

-The NSX Edge node must be available in the SDDC Manager inventory.

-The NSX Edge cluster must be hosted on one or more vSphere clusters from the same workload domain.

-The NSX Edge cluster must contain more than two NSX Edge nodes.

-The NSX Edge cluster must not be federated or stretched.

-If the NSX Edge cluster was deployed with a Tier-0 Service High Availability of Active-Active, the NSX Edge cluster must contain two or more NSX Edge nodes with two or more Tier-0 routers (SR component) after the NSX Edge nodes are removed.

-If selected edge cluster was deployed with a Tier-0 Service High Availability of Active-Standby, you cannot remove NSX Edge nodes that are the active or standby node for the Tier-0 router."

I'd go with B, C, E.

-YoMeroElParcero

BCE is correct - D is wrong, because it requires more than 2 nodes, not two nodes 

The NSX Edge cluster must contain more than two NSX Edge nodes.

questions.question_text:
A VMware administrator is deploying a NSX Edge cluster using SDDC Manager. The manager wants to know if the NSX Edge nodes can be removed at a later time, knowing that there is no budget for adding additional hardware to the VMware Cloud Foundation (VCF) infrastructure.

Which three statements accurately answer this manager’s question about NSX Edge nodes? (Choose three.)

choices.C: They can only be removed if the NSX Edge cluster is not stretched.
choices.B: They can only be removed if the NSX Edge cluster is available in the SDDC Manager inventory and is active.
choices.D: They can be removed if there are at least two nodes in the NSX Edge cluster.
choices.F: They can only be removed if the NSX Edge node was deployed from NSX-T Manager directly.
choices.A: They can be removed at any time if they are in a powered-off state.
choices.E: They can only be removed if the NSX Edge node is available in the SDDC Manager inventory.

choices.B: Small vCenter Server appliance with X-Large storage size
choices.A: Large vCenter Server appliance with default storage size
choices.C: Medium vCenter Server appliance with large storage size
choices.D: Medium vCenter Server appliance with default storage size

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Agreed. It is A.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vcenter.install.doc/GUID-FB268055-5D36-4624-A64C-9800D3FCB689.html

Answer should be A. vCenter for Large environment (up to 1,000 hosts or 10,000 virtual machines) C. is for a medium vCenter server which supports (up to 400 hosts or 4,000 virtual machines). The VI W. Domain has 5000...Medium is not the adequate appliance size.

questions.question_text:
A VMware architect has been tasked to deploy a VCF environment for a large federal organization. Security, availability, and redundancy are key requirements for the deployment. The administrator has been asked to keep the cost down as well.

A standard deployment of VCF is being planned for the headquarters. The first VI domain is estimated to have 5,000 VMs.

Which vCenter Server appliance sizing should the architect use for the VI workload domain?
